page.title: 01Staploe Parish, Geography.
page.content: Staploe parish in North Eastern Bedfordshire is bounded North and East by Cambridgeshire. This gently undulating area, just west of the main Ouse Valley, is drained by two small tributary streams, Honeydon and Duloe Brooks. The largest body of surface water is the farm resevoir at Lower Honeydon. Duloe Brook has a series of small lakes, retained by sluice and a scattering of farm ponds remain unfilled, a notably large one at Goodwick. Oxford clay rocks, here are thickly covered by chalky boulder clay, Glacial sands are exposed beside Duloe Brook at Bushmead and alluvium lines the stream valley. Visually the North-West and South-East of the Parish are sharply contrasted. Around Bushmead the "ancient" landscape and Eastwards the large open fields.
